hintText: bold:(Hint:) Kliknite na text pre zobrazenie detailov!

skills.popupDetailsText:
My programming journey began in my freshman year of high school, sparked by the bold:(Zenit competition). I started with bold:(Python), then quickly adopted bold:(C++) for its performance in competitive programming, including the bold:(Informatics Olympiad) (twice succeeded in regionals, both times bold:(very close to nationals)). This honed my skills in bold:(optimization), bold:(graph theory) or generally in bold:(logical thinking). I also played with bold:(LeetCode) for additional programming challenges.

In university, I've expanded my toolkit with bold:(Java), bold:(Go) (concurrency), bold:(Haskell) (functional programming), bold:(C) (system programming), bold:(CL) (a Specification and Verification paradigm, a university special), and web technologies (bold:(HTML), bold:(CSS), bold:(JS), bold:(PHP)). I have applied these skills to solve diverse problems, from competitive algorithms to practical automation scripts in Excel or other tools that make life easier or better.

My passion for math was ignited in 5th grade with the bold:(Math Olympiad). Since then, I've actively competed in major Slovak math contests (bold:(Math Olympiad), bold:(Klokan), bold:(Naboj), and more). Since the 7th grade in primary school, I often studied bold:(advanced topics independently), even those covered later at university. To this very day I explore math in my free time. Recently I've been particularly interested in bold:(Game theory), bold:(Probability) and bold:(Graph thoery).

My experience from competitive programming (bold:(Math Olympiad), bold:(Informatics Olympiad), bold:(KSP), etc.) has provided extensive practice in designing and implementing bold:(efficient algorithms, data structures or strategies). I'm comfortable with areas like bold:(optimization), bold:(graph theory), bold:(probability), bold:(geometry), bold:(dynamic programming), and pretty much any other common problem-solving technique.

My journey through various academic competitions (Math, History, Chemistry, Geography) and the necessity to learn and understand programming languages (bold:(Python) to bold:(C++) for speed in contests, then learning bold:(Java), bold:(Go), bold:(Haskell), etc., at university, bold:(Django), bold:(CSS), bold:(JavaScript), etc., at work) demonstrate my ability to bold:(learn new concepts and tools rapidly). I enjoy being challenged and like the feeling of bold:(mastering a new skill).

My experience with challenging math and programming seminars, similar to bold:(KSP), where I dedicated significant effort (sometimes sacrificing sleep and food) to solve complex problems and ultimately succeeded (a bold:(top 10 rank twice in a row in KSP)), taught me the value of perseverance. It's not just about talent for me; it's about bold:(enduring hardships to achieve a goal). This dedication led to my acceptance at bold:(Matfyz) with a bold:(motivational scholarship).

I also competed in KMS or STROM, where I was successful as well (around 30th-50th place), but it wasn't as great of a success as KSP.

I enjoy identifying opportunities for automation.

For example, I developed bold:(TypeScript scripts) to automate repetitive data checking and summarization tasks in Excel for my mother, bold:(saving her significant time).

Or created tools that helped me save huge amounts of time with my homework. For example, a program that would parse the online editor, designed by our teachers, to a text file and integrating tools that have found closed tableaus or formalizations in seconds, then automatically re-parsing it back into the required online editor format. Saving around half and hour for each tableau I didn't have to solve by hand.

This highlights my ability to apply programming skills to bold:(solve real-world problems efficiently).

I appreciate almost any type of humor and find it nearly impossible to feel offended by a joke. I believe this contributes to a bold:(positive and resilient team atmosphere). Importantly, I also understand the importance of context and know when to be lighthearted and when to be serious and focused.

I have studied English in school since the 2nd grade of primary school. I successfully completed my maturity exams (bold:(Maturita)) with a result in the bold:(>85th percentile), achieving a bold:(B2 level) of proficiency according to the CEFR.

I have studied Russian in school since the 5th grade of primary school. I continued to study it in high school, where I achieved a bold:(B1 level) of proficiency according to the CEFR. Although I didn't expect it, it turned out to be very handy, as it is easier for me to communicate with my Ukrainian fellow students.

education.popupDetailsText: Throughout my time at Primary School Strážske, I consistently achieved bold:(top grades (straight 1s)). It was here, particularly from 5th grade onwards, that I discovered my deep interest and aptitude for math, sparked by my participation in the bold:(Math Olympiad). This period also marked the beginning of my involvement in competitive volleyball, where our team achieved national success, including a bold:(3rd place finish in the U15 Nationals).

details: In a class focused on Math and Informatics
education.popupTitle: Gymnasium P. Horova - Igniting Programming Passion
education.popupDetailsText: At Gymnasium P. Horova, I continued to excel academically, bold:(maintaining top grades) while focusing on Math and Informatics. This is where my passion for programming truly ignited, largely thanks to participating in the bold:(Zenit competition) and to my dedicated teachers. I realized programming was like bold:('math, but better,') leading me to dive into bold:(Python) and later bold:(C++). I also continued playing volleyball throughout high school, balancing academics with team sports. This period was instrumental in developing my problem-solving skills through various Olympiads and programming challenges.

details: Matfyz (Faculty of Mathematics, Physics and Informatics)
education.popupDetailsText:
At bold:(Matfyz (Comenius University)), I am in the Applied Informatics program, maintaining a bold:(GPA of ~1.04 over two years). The challenging curriculum 'forces' me to continuously learn and solve complex problems. I've gained practical experience in web development (bold:(HTML), bold:(CSS), bold:(JS), bold:(PHP)), concurrency (bold:(Go)), functional programming (bold:(Haskell)), specification-verification (bold:(CL)), system programming (bold:(C)), and further honed my problem-solving skills in bold:(Python), bold:(Java), and bold:(C++).

This school has also taught me a great deal about bold:(advanced probability) and bold:(hypothesis testing). It has allowed me to utilize my knowledge in bold:(mathematical analysis) and bold:(linear algebra). Most recently I've learned how to bold:(write formal proofs), an area with which I previously struggled.

aboutMe: bold:(Informatics student) with a strong foundation in math and problem-solving, honed through years of competing in math and informatics.

Seeking a part-time or internship opportunity where I can contribute to innovative projects, further develop my technical skills, and learn from experienced professionals. I am not searching for a specific type of role. I would genuinely enjoy any role involving programming and critical thinking, such as bold:(Web Development), bold:(Data Science), bold:(AI), bold:(Game Development), bold:(Automation), bold:(applied Mathematics), or even bold:(Research/Science). I prefer working from office to working from home.

projects.summary: Graph Neural Networks - Partial automorphism extendability
projects.popupDetailsText: This is my bachelor thesis, which I am currently working on. It involves the use of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to solve the problem of partial automorphism extendability. The goal is to develop a GNN model that can predict whether a given partial automorphism can be extended to a full automorphism given graph and some partial automorphism. This project combines my interests in graph theory and machine learning. There is no dataset available for this, so I had to create one from scratch. It was okay. Regarding GNN and whether or not this AI will or will not be able to predict the extendability, I am not sure yet. I am still in the process of training the model and evaluating its performance.

projects.summary: Pocket Maturita - app that has helped hundreds of students prepare for Maturita
projects.popupDetailsText: I worked on this in team in high school. It was my first collaborative project. I understood that the hardest part was to actually fill in the data needed to create an app for study. There was no ChatGPT back then :D. Regarding the development there sure were complications, but they were there mostly because we were beginners.

projects.summary: Excel - Office scripts for accounting specialist that saved hours
projects.popupDetailsText: I created several automation scripts in Excel using Office Scripts for my mother, who is an accounting specialist. These scripts automate tasks that require a lot of focus and stamina, while not being really interesting to do (i.e. checking if all data are correct, or creating summaries), significantly reducing the time she spends on these tasks. This project not only improved my skills in Excel and scripting, but also showed me that if I put myself into something, I can do it.

projects.summary: Catan Board Generator that generates balanced boards
projects.popupDetailsText:
Whenever I won a game of Catan, I had to listen to my friends complaining that the board was unbalanced, that it was pure luck, etc. So I decided to create a Catan Board Generator that generates balanced boards. It is basic backtracking algorithm that generates boards until it finds a balanced one based on some rules, that I try to check optimally. I use it as PWA on my phone.

Github: link:github.com/Vl4dk0/CatanBoardGenerator

Website: link:catanboardgen.netlify.app

projects.summary: API for PONG game that allows you to create your own Racket-controlling AI
projects.popupDetailsText:
I had a great teacher in high school, who asked me to teach students for 2 lessons when she was absent. I decided to follow some tutorial to create a PONG game in python and then created an API so that you could program a Bot that will play. I then explained the topic of classes and inheritance. We then ran a tournament of our bots.

Github: link:github.com/Vl4dk0/pOnG

experience.popupDetailsText: While this role is different from the positions I am currently seeking, it was my bold:(first job) and I learned a lot about myself from it. I learned how to bold:(communicate with frustrated customers), how to bold:(work in a team), and how to bold:(plan my time effectively). I also learned about myself that I can finish a job even if I don't particularly enjoy it. bold:(I won't collapse under pressure).

experience.popupTitle: SmartBase s.r.o - Junior Django Fullstack developer
experience.popupDetailsText:
At SmartBase s.r.o (June 2024 - April 2025), I worked as a bold:(Junior Fullstack Developer) on e-commerce projects like link:alo.sk, link:argus.sk, and link:najlekaren.sk. Initially focused on frontend tasks (HTML, CSS, JavaScript from Figma templates), I quickly transitioned to backend responsibilities as well. Most interesting backend tasks were about bold:(integrating payment APIs) and bold:(optimizing image loading) to reduce users' mobile data consumption.

I greatly valued the learning experience and the team environment. We parted ways amicably as my university commitments required more time than I could dedicate to the role, and for me, bold:(studies come first).

achievements.introText: Since the 5th grade of primary school I have regularly placed in bold:(top positions) in various mathematical competitions. Thanks to a bold:(good foundation in math), I learned to bold:(program) and solve bold:(algorithmic problems very quickly and easily), which is why I started to bold:(compete in programming) as well.

subsections.title: My greatest accomplishments in High School:

items.summary: Qualifying for the national round of Math Olympiad
items.popupDetailsText: Qualifying for the bold:(national round of the Math Olympiad) was a bold:(significant personal achievement). It involved months of preparation, tackling complex problems, and it was an honor to compete at that level. This experience greatly sharpened my analytical and problem-solving abilities.

bold:(KSP (Korešpondenčný Seminár z Programovania)) was a turning point. To qualify, I dedicated immense effort to solving difficult problems, often working through the night. Achieving a bold:(top 10 rank twice in a row) wasn't just about skill; it was a testament to my ability to endure and persevere. This success directly contributed to my acceptance into bold:(Matfyz) with a bold:(motivational scholarship). I am now a proud member of the KSP team, where I help prepare problems for contests.

This competition sparked my interest in competitive programming. It was my first programming competition. In my last year of high school, I achieved bold:(2nd place in the regional round) of the Zenit competition in programming (Košice region), which also corresponded to a bold:(10th place finish nationwide). This was a great success for me.

Scored in the bold:(>96th percentile) in the written part of the bold:(Maturita (Slovak school-leaving exam)) in Math, demonstrating a strong proficiency in the subject.

However, I was not entirely satisfied with my result, as I was aiming for 100% and I missed it by 3 points. This experience taught me the importance of double-checking, as all the mistakes came from incorrectly rewriting/misspelling data from the statement.

This competition involved creating three games using Python's Tkinter module. There were over 40 winners, that (for unknown reasons) were not sorted by submition time. The contest was intended to be fun rather than prestigious, but achieving a bold:(100% score) was necessary to be recognized as a winner.

This was a pair-programming competition focused on solving four challenging problems within four hours. I participated with my friend, and we achieved bold:(3rd place in the national round), which was a great achievement for us.

Maintaining a bold:(1.04 GPA) in my initial semesters reflects my dedication to my studies and my ability to grasp complex concepts in informatics and math quickly. (Note: In Slovakia, 1.0 is the best possible grade).

I've actively played volleyball since 5th grade in primary school, competing at a national level. Our team achieved bold:(3rd place in the U15 Nationals) one year and 6th the following. This sport has taught me valuable lessons in bold:(teamwork), bold:(discipline), bold:(respect) (particularly for our coach), and maintaining an active lifestyle.
